bibl.title: Letter from Edward Champe Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, May 17, 1935

div1.p: Carter congratulates his sister on her upcoming wedding and offers to pay for the flowers. He does not want the bride and groom to visit him in the hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Edward Champe Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, May 17, 1935

opener.dateline:
Western State Hospital,
Staunton, Va.
May 17, 1935.

div1.p:
Received your note a few minutes ago. I am very glad that so much
happiness has now come your way. And I know that to be part of “the Ser-
vice” will always make life full and interesting to you. The Admiral
merits considerable congratulating.

About not wishing me to go to the wedding; that is quite alright.
Dr. DeJarnette would, of course, have let me go, as he would anywhere;
let alone my sister's wedding. But I know Ashland does not love me; it
is tragic how much better the people who know me and are close to me love
me and believe in me than my immediate family (Dr. Freed says it is the
rule, not the exception). But I wish you all manner of happiness, and
I feel perfectly sure you will find it.

I think we each have a right to be frank. You have already been
so about my not going to Ashland to your wedding, and so I will take my
turn and say that I think it would be a great mistake for you and the
Admiral to stop by here at all on your wedding trip. I even think it
would be mad taste. This place is an insane asylum, and that's that. I
would suggest, and urge, that you do not even think of paying me a visit
here at Western State. At some future time maybe you and the Admiral and
I will meet. I mean this request just as fully as I know you meant
yours about me. I am not very well any more, physically (mentally, I am
better than I have ever been), and the more even the keel on which I go
the less attacks I have; and I find NOTHING is worth an attack, though in
my whole life no physicians have been as good to me as all six of the
doctors here are all the time now.

I believe that it is the custom for the bridgegroom to igive the flowers
at a wedding, but, as a shut-in and a shut-out, I would like it if you would
tell Carter Redd that I want to give you your flowers, and I want to pay
the right amount of them; that is to as much as fifteen dollars. I KNOW
I have enough money in bank to do that, and still take care of my own
regular monthly comforts and medicinal needs (about which I wrote Carter
yesterday, through Dr. DeJarnette). And I would like you to pick out
just the right flowers, and the correct flowers from a really good Richmond
florist, or have them sent from Washington, as you see fit.

Harry Thomas is doing fine in New York and all of us here are so
proud of him; the Doctors here make as big a fuss over him, almost, as I
do. LaF rge counts him among his “best bets for the future”.

Wishing you every happiness, and congratulating the Admiral, and
hoping you will respect my rwquest as I am respecting yours, and hoping
that, under the circunstances, you will see to those flowers AND HAVE THEM
RIGHT IN EVERY DETAIL, And tell Carter so, and with dear love to you,
div1.closer: Your affectionate brother, Ned, Edward C. Carter.
